KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|MERP Dead standing litter study data (1985-1989) methods
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Definitions:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-All standing litter: on dry sites, all litter that is not lying horizontal on the ground (from the previous August).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Aerial standing litter: dead plants, in flooded sites, that are not toppled, i.e. a portion of a shoot which protrudes above the water surface (from the previous August).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Aerial standing live shoots: live plants, in flooded sites, that are not toppled, i.e. a portion of a shoot which protrudes above the water surface.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Flooded standing live shoots: live plants, in flooded sites, that are not toppled, i.e. a portion of a shoot which is completely submersed or laying on the water surface.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The purpose of this study was to estimate annual standing litter production by monitoring standing litter biomass and nutrient concentration. During both early May and August collections, ‘clip quadrats’ of 1m x 1m were used to monitor standing crops of biomass, nitrogen, phosphorus and carbon. In May collections, only aerial standing litter (dead) was sampled at dry and flooded sites. In August collections, aerial standing litter (dead, at dry and flooded sites), as well as aerial standing live shoots and flooded standing live shoots (at flooded sites) were sampled, keeping the flooded and aerial portions of a stem separate. The experimental time frame was May 1985 to August 1989 (Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Approximately 150 established research sites (15 sites per each of the 10 MERP cells) were utilized. The criteria for site selection was to represent the natural depth range for each species. New sites were selected when vegetation became sparse or void on previously selected sites. Each site was marked by a numbered stake. Sampling required that 1m x 1m quadrats be clipped at all sites. A randomly selected, undisturbed plot was located within 2 meters of the site marker stake. All clip data was recorded on the standing litter clip plot field sheets. Month of sampling and quadrat moisture condition (dry vs. flooded) determined the incumbent sampling schedule (with the exception of 1985; Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|At each dry site, only dead standing shoots within the quadrat were clipped. As with aboveground macrophyte sampling (contained within a separate data package on the KNB), large hand clippers were used, clipping all standing dead shoots rooted within the quadrat. The same general procedure was followed at flooded sites, with the exception that water depth was recorded at the center of each quadrat, and both aerial and flooded portions of a shoot, as well as live and dead (depending on sampling month), were collected and kept separately. For both dry and flooded sites, if a plant was rooted within the quadrat, all foliage was included with the sample even if it extended beyond the quadrat bounds. Within a quadrat, all dominant emergent species (i.e. Typha glauca syn. Typha × glauca, Phragmites australis, Carex atherodes, Scirpus validus syn. Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani, Scirpus acutus syn. Schoenoplectus acutus, Scirpus maritimus, Scolochloa festucacea; for 1985, dominant species also included Aster brachyactis syn. Symphytotrichum ciliatum, Atriplex patula, Chenopodium rubrum and Sonchus arvensis), and any additional species with greater than 25% cover, were treated separately. Other species with less than 25% cover were combined and labeled “minor species”. After clipping, these sorted plants were placed into separate paper bags and labeled by 1) species name, 2) collection date, 3) site number, 4) cell, 5) moisture condition along with clip type (i.e. dry standing litter, aerial standing litter, aerial standing live shoots, flooded standing live shoots). Aerial standing litter (dead) was assumed to be from the previous year with the exception of Phragmites, which can persist for one or more years and therefore was separated as fresh litter (shiny; tan color) or old litter (dull; grey color; Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|All litter samples were immediately dried to constant weight (80 degrees Celcius) in the drying room. If necessary, samples were stored in the cold room until space was available in the drying room. Once dried to constant weight (80 degrees Celcius), each sampled was placed in a paper bag and reweighed to 0.01g accuracy. Both weights were recorded on the standing litter clip plot field sheets. All dried samples were ground in a 40-mesh Wiley mill and each stored in Whirlpak bags. A single sample which occupied more than one storage bag was subsampled at random from all storage bags, taking care to include plant parts in proportion to their relative biomass within the sample (Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989). Clip quadrat samples were analyzed for nutrient (phosphorus, carbon and nitrogen) concentrations by Iowa State University. To reduce costs, only three samples from each species (Aster brachyactis syn. Symphytotrichum ciliatum, Chenopodium rubrum, Sonchus arvensis, Cirsium arvense, Atriplex patula, Mentha arvensis, Hordeum jubatum, Salix sp., Typha glauca syn. Typha × glauca, Phragmites australis, Scolochloa festucacea, Scirpus maritimus, Scirpus validus, Carex atherodes) and litter type (aerial and dead samples for spring 1985, fall 1985 and spring 1986, as well as aerial and live, aerial and dead, flooded and live, and flooded and dead for fall 1986) combination were randomly selected for nutrient analysis, and only from the 1985-1986 sampling period.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|References:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Murkin, H.R., A.G. van der Valk and J.W. Nelson. 1989. Decomposition. In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Eds.) E.J. Murkin and H.R. Murkin, pp. 31-34. Manitoba, Canada: Delta Waterfowl Research Station.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Marsh Ecology Research Program: Objectives, study area and experimental design (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Introduction
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Good et al. (1978) and Greeson et al. (1978) were among the first to summarize the state of our understanding in freshwater wetland ecology. They emphasized the need for expanded interdisciplinary research in freshwater wetlands. Ten years later, van der Valk (1989), in Northern Prairie Wetlands, focused specifically on prairie wetlands and the influence of water-level changes on the dynamics and productivity of these systems.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Primary production, secondary production, vegetation composition and distribution, animal use, and nutrient budgets are all affected as water levels rise and fall with variation in precipitation. Ranging from tiny potholes to huge lacustrine complexes, prairie wetlands are among the world's most productive ecosystems (Murkin, 1989a). Their importance as wildlife production areas has drawn considerable attention to their conservation and management (Weller, 1978; Weller, 1981). This attention has increased in recent years with the need for information on the overall functions and values of wetlands within the prairie landscape (Murkin, 1998). Understanding wetland values is critical to the development of comprehensive wetland conservation programs. In addition, the ongoing destruction of wetlands through drainage, urban sprawl, and other human-induced changes has added a great deal of urgency to the need for a better understanding of the ecology and management of all remaining wetland areas (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Objectives
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Recognizing the need for an improved understanding of prairie wetland ecology, the Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP) was initiated in 1979 as a joint project of
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Ducks Unlimited Canada and the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station (Murkin et al., 1984). The MERP was designed as a long-term replicated experiment addressing the impacts of various water levels on the main components of the prairie wetland ecosystem. The overall objective of MERP was to document the changes that occur within a prairie wetland during a simulated wet-dry cycle (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). More specifically, MERP was designed to determine the storage (pools) and movement (fluxes) of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and carbon (C) during the various stages of the cycle (Murkin et al., 2000a). Specific objectives for each of the major ecosystem components were as follows:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|1. Hydrology: to estimate the terms of the water budget during all stages of the wet-dry cycle: surface water in and out, ground water in and out, change in storage, precipitation, and evapotranspiration.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|2. Water chemistry: to estimate the concentrations of N, P, C, and major ions in both surface and substrate pore-water pools and to monitor changes in these pools during the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|3. Macrophytes: to estimate annual above- and below ground macrophyte productivity and standing crops and subsequent changes related to the wet-dry cycle. Storage and movement of N, P, and C in macrophytes during the wet-dry cycle also were determined.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|4. Macrophyte litter: to estimate the annual production of above- and belowground macrophyte litter and the loss and uptake of N, P, and C to and from the litter compartment.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|5. Algae: to estimate algal standing crops and productivity (phytoplankton, epiphyton, epipelon, and metaphyton) during the various stages of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|6. Invertebrates: to estimate standing crops of invertebrates (nekton, benthos, and emerging insects) during the various phases of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|7. Vertebrates: to monitor use by waterfowl, coots, blackbirds, and muskrats in response to habitat changes during the wet- dry cycle.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP experimental design and field-sampling protocols were developed to meet these objectives. Nutrient data were used to construct nutrient budgets for the experimental cells. Several additional objectives beyond those related specifically to nutrient storage and movement also were addressed. Examples are rate of recovery of plant communities following drawdown (Welling et al., 1988a), habitat use by various vertebrate groups during specific stages of the wet-dry cycle (Clark and Kroeker, 1993), and the effect of the wet-dry cycle on individual invertebrate species (Ross and Murkin, 1993; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Study Area
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP study area was located on the Delta Marsh in south-central Manitoba, Canada (5011'N, 98°19'W). The Delta Marsh is a large lacustrine marsh (15,000 ha) along the southern shore of Lake Manitoba (see Batt, 2000). The marsh is of Pleistocene origin and is a remnant of glacial Lake Agassiz (Löve and Löve, 1954, Ehrlich et al., 1957). An important feature of the marsh is that its water level has been stabilized for many years (due to installation of a water-control structure on Lake Manitoba in 1961), resulting in lake marsh conditions described by van der Valk and Davis (1978) over much of its area (Murkin et al., 2000a). The site for the MERP experimental complex was chosen because of several features. First, the area had representative portions of shallow- and deep-marsh zones characteristic of the Delta Marsh and other northern prairie marshes. Second, the area was remote and completely within the private ownership of the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station, thus ensuring access for researchers, while affording effective control of trespass and disturbance. Third, the site was served by an existing road system. This road system was crucial, given the large number of individuals working on the site each day; the large numbers and volumes of water, soil, vegetation, and animal samples to be handled; and the logistics of transporting and maintaining sampling devices. Finally, the existing road provided the northern boundary of the experimental cells, thereby reducing construction costs. The water levels used in the experiments were chosen to reflect conditions that had occurred naturally during the previous 5 decades. Thus, the experimental site and design has provided information that is relevant to any future management efforts on the Delta Marsh, specifically, and wetland management in general.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The experimental cell complex consisted of 10 contiguous 4-6 ha marsh units (Cells 1-10), created in 1979 by building a series of dikes along the northern edge of the main marsh. The diked experimental cells were numbered 1 to 10 from west to east. The approximate dimension of each diked cell was 150m x 300m (see Table 1 for the specific dimensions of each cell). Disturbance due to dike construction was confined to the dikes and a 10m buffer strip on each side of the dike. Each diked cell was equipped with a water control structure and electric pump with automatic controls to adjust and maintain (2cm) water levels according to the schedule (see Table 2). Besides the diked cells, two undiked areas of similar size within the Delta Marsh (Cells 11 & 12) were monitored as reference cells (i.e. reference cells to the unmanipulated Delta Marsh). The vegetation within the diked cells prior to the experimental treatments was comparable to the reference cells and main Delta Marsh (Pederson 1981; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Experimental Design
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The general MERP objective was to monitor the response of various aspects of the wetland ecosystem to a series of water-level manipulations intended to simulate the wet-dry cycle of prairie wetlands. The schedule for water-level treatments and the number of replicates for each treatment are shown in Tables 2 and 3. The study was basically divided into four phases. The first two phases (baseline and deep flooding) were designed to provide background information on the experimental cells and to bring all cells to a similar condition (lake marsh stage) before the actual wet-dry cycle was applied during the last two phases (drawdown and reflooding; Murkin et al., 2000a). The four phases of the experimental design were as follows:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|a. Baseline year (1980-1981):
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|During the first year of the study (1980), the control structures were left open and water levels within the cells were allowed to track the levels of the Delta Marsh. This method provided a year of baseline data before the actual water-level manipulations began. Two of the cells (3 and 7) were kept at baseline levels for a second year (1981) to allow for comparison of different durations of drawdown later in the study (see Table 3).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|b. Deep flooding (aka Conditioning Period; 1981-1983):
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Following the baseline year(s), all diked cells were flooded to ~ 1 m above normal for a period of 2 years (Table 2). These levels were designed to flood the existing cattail (Typha spp.) stands to a depth of 1 m and were similar to actual natural high-water levels that occurred in the Delta Marsh in the 1950s. This deep flooding was intended to kill the existing emergent vegetation and set all the cells to the lake marsh stage described by van der Valk and Davis (1978). In part, deep flooding was also an attempt to reduce the variability in vegetation among the experimental cells prior to drawdown.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|c. Drawdown (1983-1984):
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|After the second year of above-normal flooding, the cells were drawn down (completely dewatered) by adjusting the water levels to 50 cm below the long-term level of the Delta Marsh (Table 2). Most cells were exposed to a 2-year drawdown. Two cells (3 and 7) were drawn down for 1 year to allow comparisons between drawdowns of 1- and 2-year durations. The drawdowns allowed vegetation to reestablish on the marsh substrates (Welling et al., 1988a, b).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|d. Reflooding (1985-1989):
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|It has been assumed that the rate at which prairie wetlands proceed through the various stages of the wet-dry cycle is determined by water depth, with deeper wetlands moving to the lake marsh stage more quickly than shallowly flooded wetlands (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). Following drawdown, the cells were reflooded to three different levels (Table 3). The normal level was the long-term mean level (247.50 m above mean sea level [AMSL]) of the Delta Marsh and the medium (247.80 m) and high (248.10 m) levels were 30 and 60 cm above the long-term mean, respectively (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To ensure replicated treatments (on a hydrologic basis) during the reflooding experiments in 1985-1989, water-level treatments were assigned to the experimental cells as follows: the two low-water treatments with a 1-year drawdown (Table 3) were randomly assigned to the experimental complex, and the remaining treatments were then assigned to the other cells to ensure that each cell within a water-level treatment had a similar hydrologic setting (i.e. both low cells with 1-year drawdowns were flanked by cells with low and high treatments, both low 2-year drawdown cells by low and medium treatments, all medium treatment cells by high- and low-treatment cells, and the high-treatment cells by medium and low cells). This replicated hydrology is discussed in more detail in Kadlec (1983, 1993). The treatment assignments for the 1985-1989 period (Table 3) determined the water-level assignments during the early phases of the MERP experiments from 1981 to 1984 (Table 2).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Long-term Monitoring Program
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The Scientific Team designed a program of standardized methods to monitor the experimental cells throughout the period of study. The basic strategy was to collect a comparable data set from year to year in each experimental cell for each of the major components being monitored, including hydrology, water chemistry, macrophytes, macrophyte litter, algae, invertebrates and vertebrates (Murkin et al., 2000a; Murkin, 1989b). The MERP long-term monitoring program involved a variety of techniques that were used to provide comparable datasets across the experimental cells and over the 10 years of fieldwork. Some of the techniques used were new, but most were adopted from other researchers. All have been modified to suit the needs for efficiency, economy and practicality for long-term large-scale ecosystem research (Murkin et al., 2000b). Each component has a section in the MERP Data Archive describing the techniques used.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Short-term Studies
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Besides the long-term monitoring program, short-term studies were an integral component of the overall MERP program. Some of these studies provided background information needed to develop the long-term monitoring program (Pederson, 1981; Wrubleski, 1984). Some were integrated into the long-term monitoring program (Murkin, 1983a; Galinato, 1985; Hosseini, 1986; Welling, 1987; Merendino, 1989). Several aspects of the long-term monitoring program following drawdown began as short-term studies (Kroeker, 1988; Squires, 1991; Wrubleksi, 1991). Many of the short-term studies, however, were initiated because of questions raised by the long-term monitoring program. This approach was particularly true for studies of invertebrates (Nelson, 1982; Neckles, 1984; Bicknese, 1987; Campeau, 1990) and emergent macrophytes (Neill, 1988; Neill, 1992). Many of the short-term studies were conducted by graduate studies, a list of which can be found in merp_pubs_appx3_prairie_wetland_ecology_pdfa.pdf and whose theses can be found in the merp_publications_theses file (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Main Transects, Work Lanes and Sampling Procedure
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To aid in the assignment of sampling stations, each cell was divided into 10 zones. Zone boundaries were parallel to the southern dike. To determine the zones, 10 areas of equal width were established between a line 10 m north of the south dike and a second line 10 m south of the road on the northern edge of the cell. These zones were permanently marked so they could be located from year to year.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Each year, ten transects were randomly established within each cell, 1 per zone, numbered from north to south. These transects or ‘work lanes’ were used for all types of routine sampling, in order to minimize disturbance and confine it within a designated region. All sampling took place as near as possible to the work lane. When a sampling point was some distance from the work lane, a path perpendicular to the work lane was established. Work lanes were reassigned each fall following the last day of sampling (Murkin, 1989b; Murkin et al., 2000b).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|A standard sampling procedure was maintained during all transect sampling. One or two random transects in each cell were sampled, repeating the same method for each cell until all samples were secured, rather than sampling all transects in a cell before moving on to the next cell. This randomized any effect due to time during the sampling period. As standard procedure, water depth at the sampling site was recorded during all types of sampling (Murkin, 1983b).
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Additional data packages generated from the Marsh Ecology Research Program can also be found on the Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity (KNB):
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|AERIAL MAPS & GIS
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Aerial photos, cover maps and GIS data (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|ALGAE:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Algal data transect sampling (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Metaphyton data (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Epipelon data (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Epiphyton data (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Phytoplankton data (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|ANNUAL CLIMATIC FACTORS:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Weather data (1980-1989)

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Decomposition of mud-flat species litter bag study data (1985-1987)

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|HYDROLOGY:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Hydraulic conductivity data (1982-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Water table levels (1982-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Pump meter data (1980-1989)

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|INVERTEBRATES:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Artificial substrates data (1985-1989)

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT:

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|SOIL NUTRIENTS:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Soil nutrients and groundwater well site characterization data (1980-1985)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|VEGETATION:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Matching stems study data (1986-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Belowground macrophyte production data (MBG; 1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Aboveground macrophyte production data (MAG; 1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Turnover plot data (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|VERTEBRATES:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Nest count data (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Avian census data (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Muskrat habitat selection data (1986)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Muskrat population data (1985-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|WATER CHEMISTRY:
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Water chemistry data (1980-1989)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Tables
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Table 1: Dimensions of the MERP cells (from Murkin, 1983b)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Cells Width (m)a Length (m)b Work zone width (m) Area (ha)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|1 155 300 30 5.68
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|2 190 300 30 7.5
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|3 130 330 33 5.48
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|4 135 310 31 6.08

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|a - measured from a point 10m east of the borrow ditch to a second point 10m west of the east dike. Since the width of an individual cell varies from north to south these are the mean values.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|b - measured from a line 10m north of the south dike to a parallel line 10m south of the north edge of the cell.

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|quadrats (1m x 1m) were clipped in May and August of each year. Starting in 1986, the sampling month determined the type of litter (i.e. live or dead, aerial or flooded) which was collected. 1985: 8-10,14-18,20-24,27,28-May-1985; 11,16-18-September-1985 1986: 13-16,19-22,27-May-1986 and 3-June-1986 (considered 'May' sampling period); 12-15,18-22,25-29-August-1986 and 17,18-September-1986 (considered 'August' sampling period) 1987: 21-22,25-27,29-May-1987 and 1-2,4-5,8-June-1987 (considered 'May' sampling period); 7,10-12,14,18,24-27-August-1987 1988: 8-10,13-June-1988 (considered 'May' sampling period); 24-26,29-August-1988 1989: 15-17,23-May-1989; 30,31-August-1989 and 4,5,7-September-1989 (considered 'August' sampling period)

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1322086291328
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|cell_num
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|cell number
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Approximately 15 sites per cell were utilized. However, new sites were added when vegetation became sparse or void on previously selected sites. cells were numbered 1 to 10 from west to east in the diked study area.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/measurementScale/nominal/nonNumericDomain/textDomain/definition|cell number (1-10)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1322086291343
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|site
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|site number
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Approximately 15 sites per cell were utilized, for a total of 150 sites. However, new sites were added when vegetation became sparse or void on previously selected sites. 1985: 1-150 1986: 1-180 (1-189 fall 1986) 1987: 1-187 (1-215 fall 1987) 1988: 3-215 (1-220 fall 1988) 1989: 1-220 Note: For an unknown reason, the number of sites sampled is reduced from ~150 (from 1985 to spring 1987), to ~60 (from fall 1987 to 1989). As the dead standing litter (1985-1989) data was never published, no reason can be given as to this change in methodology; however, the reduction in number of sites may have been to reduce the impact of sampling on the cells, or to reduce the workload.
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/measurementScale/nominal/nonNumericDomain/textDomain/definition|site number (1-220)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1322086291359
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|h2o_depth
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|water depth (cm)
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|water depth was recorded at the centre of each quadrat. In addition to sampling month, water depth (i.e. dry vs. flooded) also determined the type of litter sampled (i.e. if dry = aerial standing litter, if flooded = aerial standing litter, aerial standing live shoots, aerial standing flooded shoots) Note: Water depth data for Fall 1985 was only recorded on the fieldsheets as 'flooded', 'dry' or 'trace', and was therefore not included in the data file.

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|aerial_flood
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|aerial or flooded
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|1=aerial (i.e. plants that are not toppled and, if at flooded sites, above the water surface) 2=flooded (i.e. plants that are not toppled and, if at flooded sites, completely submersed or laying on top of the water surface) whether aerial or flooded shoots were sampled was determined according to the sampling month. If sampled in May, only aerial standing litter (1) was collected from dry and flooded sites. If sampled in August, aerial and flooded shoots were collected at flooded sites, as well as aerial standing litter from dry sites. The exception to this is 1985, where aerial and flooded litter was sampled in May, but only aerial litter sampled in August.

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1322086291390
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|live_dead
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|live or dead
KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|1=live 2=dead Starting in 1986, whether live or dead shoots were sampled was determined according to the sampling month. If sampled in May, only aerial standing litter (i.e. dead) was collected from dry and flooded sites. If sampled in August, live and dead shoots (i.e. aerial standing litter, aerial standing live shoots and flooded standing live shoots) were collected from flooded sites, in addition to the collection of standing litter from dry sites (note that although the Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989 MERP procedures manual methods state that in August, only dead standing litter was collected at dry sites, the dataset also contains aerial standing live shoots at dry sites. It is unknown why this data is included, and whether or not there was a change in study design which was not recorded in the MERP procedures). In 1985, only dead shoots (aerial and flooded) were collected.

KNB|00581-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Within a quadrat, all dominant emergent species (i.e. Typha glauca syn. Typha × glauca, Phragmites australis, Carex atherodes, Scirpus validus syn. Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani, Scirpus acutus syn. Schoenoplectus acutus, Scirpus maritimus, Scolochloa festucacea; for 1985, dominant species also included Aster brachyactis syn. Symphytotrichum ciliatum, Atriplex patula, Chenopodium rubrum and Sonchus arvensis ), and any additional species with greater than 25% cover, were treated separately. Other species with less than 25% cover were combined and labeled “minor species”.

KNB|00596-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|Data were collected in eight wildfire burn areas one year post-fire and eight adjacent non-burned areas. All data were collected throughout the summers of 2007 and 2008. For each tree sampled, data were recorded on mountain pine beetle colonization, fire injury category of the tree, percent basal injury, percent bole injury, percent canopy injury, cambium kill rating, mistletoe rating, blister rust lesion presence, percent slope of transect, degree aspect of transect, elevation of transect, burn or non-burn site name, size of burn, mountain pine beetle population size, year of burn, and transect name. The purpose of the data was to measure the colonization of mountain pine beetle in lodgepole pines experiencing varying degrees of fire injury.

KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/individualName/givenName|Harvey

KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/associatedParty/role|associatedParty
KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2012-05-09
KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|I took samples of plants and animals discontinuously (1975-1979) in two sites at Drum Shoals (34o 42?40?N, 76o 46?20?W) in Bogue Sound and two sites at Middle Marsh (34o 41?32?N,76o 37?20W) in Back Sound. Both are sites of eelgrass (Zostera marina) beds located in Carteret County, NC, USA. Drum Shoals is located at least 250 m from the nearest Spartina marsh whereas Middle Marsh sites are located from 10 to 80 m from the nearest Spartina marsh and are almost surrounded by it. To denude plots, I removed sediment to a depth of 5 cm in 120 squares (0.25 m2 each) with a shovel in September 1975. I sampled plants and animals using a square box quadrat macrobenthic sampler (947 cm2 bottom area ? approximately 36.5 liter volume including the top 3 cm of sediment) having 0.8 mm mesh netting. Most of the sediment was removed through the mesh sides of the sampler in the field; after transfer to buckets, samples were brought back to the lab, washed again on a 0.8 mm mesh sieve to remove residual sediment, and frozen in plastic bags. All samples were taken in the day time within +/- 3 hours of low tide; water depth was 5 to 60 cm while sampling. Samples from denuded plots were taken in the center of each plot. Fauna were separated from shell material and plant material in a white tray. Animals were identified to species except for some polychaete families.

KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/para|October 1975- December 1976 April 1977 - June 1977 Dec 1978 - April 1979
KNB|00612-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription/para|The experimental design was a split-plot in a randomized block design. The locations were divided into main plots; time of sampling (monthly) was randomly assigned among those whole plots independently at each location.

KNB|00686-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|Tree measurements, composition of vegetation and fungi, soil humidity and humus layer thickness were studied in a 5.5 ha plot in forest, which was burned in 1997 at Kolari, Finnish Lapland. Measurements before and after fire were carried out in 1997, 1998 and 2004. Aim of this study was to explore how forest fire affects in forest composition. Study was carried out by the Finnish Forest Research Institute (FFRI).

KNB|00686-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription/para|The rescue department needed a place to practice fire extinguishing, which brought an opportunity to study effects of forest firein northern boreal forest. Forest was studied before fire in 1997 by recording tree measurements, vegetation composition, soil humidity and humus layer thickness. Next year same measurements were made and in addition fungi were studied. In 2004 vegetation composition and new tree seedling were recorded. Data package contains original measurements, maps, photos and plans for future studies. Data package and description is in Finnish only. Experimental plots are still available for further measurements by permission.

KNB|00691-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|Daily count and length information 1979-2006 The State Water Project (SWP), operated by the California Department of Water Resources (DWR), and the Central Valley Project (CVP), operated by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, export water out of the San Francisco Bay Delta for urban and agricultural use in California. When water is exported, fish become entrained into the diversion. Since 1957, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) has salvaged fish at the Tracy Fish Collection Facility (TFCF). The Department of Fish and Game's Fish Facilities Unit, in cooperation with DWR, began salvaging fish at the Skinner Delta Fish Protective Facility (SDFPF) in 1968. The salvaged fish are trucked daily and released at several sites in the western Delta. The schedule of fish hauling is dependent on salvage rates, debris loading, and special-status-species procedures. Salvage of fish at both facilities is conducted 24 hours a day, seven days a week at regular intervals. Sampling of entrained fish at the SDFPF and TFCF is the source for DFG's daily salvage and loss estimates for the monitoring of incidental take of listed fish species.

KNB|00694-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/project/abstract/para|La finalidad de este proyecto es sentar las bases para el establecimiento de un observatorio permanente para evaluar los efectos del cambio global en Sierra Nevada. Nuestras premisas de partida son que, para lograr manejar los recursos de manera adaptativa, es fundamental contar con información actualizada, sistemática y de calidad sobre los distintos aspectos que configuran los sistemas naturales. También es importante que tanto la información en bruto como el conocimiento que resulta de su análisis y procesamiento, llegue a los distintos actores sociales mediante un sólido proceso de difusión de resultados.

KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|General water quality and toxicity data collected from 1998 to 2007 for compliance with National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits by the following wastewater treatment plants: Brentwood Wastewater Treatment Plant; Discovery Bay Wastewater Treatment Plant; Manteca Wastewater Treatment Plant; Merced Wastewater Treatment Plant; Modesto Wastewater Treatment Plant; Mountain House Wastewater Treatment Plant; Rio Vista Beach Wastewater Treatment Plant; Sacramento Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant; Stockton Wastewater Treatment Plant; Tracy Wastewater Treatment Plant; Turlock Wastewater Treatment Plant; White Slough Water Pollution Control Plant (City of Lodi); Vacaville Wastewater Treatment Plant. Note: These data were transcribed from Excel and pdf files for formatting purposes and are presented as provided by the wastewater treatment plants.

KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1276551397191
KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|Endpoint
KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Endpoint - Specific adverse effect analyzed in toxicity test. NOEC or NOAEC - No Observed Effect Concentration or No Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Highest concentration that did not cause adverse effect statistically different from the control. LOEC or LOAEC - Lowest Observed Effect Concentration or Lowest Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Lowest concentration that caused an effect statistically different from the control LC50 - Lethal concentration killing 50 percent of exposed organisms at specific time interval. IC25, IC50 - Inhibition concentration - statistically derived concentration that would cause a 25 or 50 percent reduction in a biological measurement such as fecundity or growth.

KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1276552836192
KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|Endpoint
KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Endpoint - Specific adverse effect analyzed in toxicity test. NOEC or NOAEC - No Observed Effect Concentration or No Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Highest concentration that did not cause adverse effect statistically different from the control. LOEC or LOAEC - Lowest Observed Effect Concentration or Lowest Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Lowest concentration that caused an effect statistically different from the control LC50 - Lethal concentration killing 50 percent of exposed organisms at specific time interval. IC25, IC50 - Inhibition concentration - statistically derived concentration that would cause a 25 or 50 percent reduction in a biological measurement such as fecundity or growth.

KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|Endpoint
KNB|00701-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|Endpoint - Specific adverse effect analyzed in toxicity test. NOEC or NOAEC - No Observed Effect Concentration or No Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Highest concentration that did not cause adverse effect statistically different from the control. LOEC or LOAEC - Lowest Observed Effect Concentration or Lowest Observed Adverse Effect Concentration - Lowest concentration that caused an effect statistically different from the control LC50 - Lethal concentration killing 50 percent of exposed organisms at specific time interval. IC25, IC50 - Inhibition concentration - statistically derived concentration that would cause a 25 or 50 percent reduction in a biological measurement such as fecundity or growth.

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/deliveryPoint|P.O. Box 1160

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/country|Canada
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|The Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP) was a long-term interdisciplinary study on the ecology of prairie wetlands. A scientific team from a variety of disciplines (hydrology, plant ecology, invertebrate ecology, vertebrate ecology, nutrient dynamics, marsh management) was assembled to design and oversee a long-term experiment on the effects of water-level manipulation on northern prairie wetlands. Ten years of fieldwork (1980 -1989), combining a routine long-term monitoring program and a series of short-term studies, generated a wealth of new and diverse information on the ecology and function of prairie wetlands (Murkin, Batt, Caldwell, Kadlec and van der Valk, 2000). This data set includes a litter bag study on shoot decomposition, collected as part of the decomposition section of MERP. The high primary productivity in wetlands ensures that plant litter production and decomposition are important factors in wetland nutrient budgets. There are 3 components of the litter pool in prairie wetlands: standing litter, fallen litter, and dissolved organic compounds that leach from both standing and fallen litter (Davis and van der Valk, 1978). Material enters the standing litter compartment with the death of the leaf or shoots. In prairie marshes, litter is transferred from the standing litter compartment to fallen litter primarily through fragmentation by wind, snow, and ice action. In areas of high muskrat activity, feeding and house building can result in living plant tissues directly entering the fallen litter stage. Once within the fallen litter compartment, decomposition rates increase due to the growth of bacteria, fungi, and other consumers on the litter particles. (Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989). The MERP decomposition studies are a series of short-term studies examining the decomposition rates of both above- and belowground components of the dominant emergent species and the transfer of litter from the standing to the fallen litter compartment within the experimental cells (Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, 1989). Three types of decomposition studies were conducted: litterbag studies, dead standing litter (clip plot) studies and matching stems (permanent clips) studies.This short-term litter bag study was conducted to examine the decomposition of emergent macrophytes (Typha glauca syn. Typha × glauca, Phragmites australis, Scolochloa festucacea, Scirpus lacustris and Scirpus maritimus syn Schoenoplectus maritimus) that dominated during the first year of reflooding (1985; Nelson, 1988; Wrubleski, Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, unpublished). For further information on the Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP), please visit: http://www.ducks.ca/conserve/research/projects/merp/index.html References: Davis, C.B. and van der Valk. 1978. The decomposition of standing and fallen litter of Typha glauca and Scirpus fluviatilis. Can. J. Bot. 56: 662-675. Murkin, H.R., B.D.J. Batt, P.J. Caldwell, J.A. Kadlec and A.G. van der Valk. 2000a. Introduction to the Marsh Ecology Research Program. In Prairie Wetland Ecology: The Contribution of the Marsh Ecology Research Program. (Eds) H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and W.R. Clark. pp. 3-15. Ames: Iowa State University Press. Nelson, J.W. and C.B. Davis. 1986. Decomposition. In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Eds.) H.R. Murkin and E.J. Murkin, pp. 57-65. Manitoba, Canada: Delta Waterfowl Research Station. Resulting Publications on MERP Decomposition studies: Murkin, H.R., A.G. van der Valk and C.B. Davis. 1989. Decomposition of four dominant macrophytes in the Delta Marsh, Manitoba. Wildl. Soc. Bull. 17: 215-221. van der Valk, A.G., J.M. Rhymer, H.R. Murkin. 1991. Flooding and the decomposition of litter of four emergent plant species in a prairie wetland. Wetlands 11 (1): 1-16. Wrubleski, D.A., H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and C.B. Davis. 1997. Decomposition of litter of three mudflat annual species in a northern prairie marsh during drawdown. Plant Ecology 129: 141-148. Wrubleski, D.A., H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and J.W. Nelson. Decomposition of Plant Litter in a Newly Flooded Northern Prairie Marsh. Unpublished manuscript. Wrubleski, D.A., H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and J.W. Nelson. 1997. Decomposition of emergent macrophyte roots and rhizomes in a northern prairie marsh. Aquatic Botany 58: 121-134. Additional MERP Publications on Decomposition Studies Neckles, H.A. and C. Neill. 1994. Hydrologic control of litter decomposition in seasonally flooded prairie marshes. Hydrobiologia 286: 155-165. Nelson, J.W., J.A. Kadlec and H.R. Murkin. 1990. Seasonal comparisons of weight loss for two types of Typha glauca Godr. leaf litter. Aquatic Botany 37: 299-314. Nelson, J.W., J.A. Kadlec and H.R. Murkin. 1990. Responses by macroinvertebrates to cattail litter quality and timing of litter submergence in a northern prairie marsh. wetlands 10: 47-60.

Please cite the owners of the data, including the principal investigator(s) and Ducks Unlimited Canada, in any publications that use this data. Although substantial efforts have been made to verify the accuracy of data and metadata contained within this data package, complete accuracy cannot be guaranteed.

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/coverage/geographicCoverage/geographicDescription|Marsh Ecology Research Complex: The MERP study area was located on the Delta Marsh in south central Manitoba, Canada. The Delta Marsh is a large lacustrine marsh (approximately 50,000 ha) along the southern shore of Lake Manitoba. The experimental complex consisted of 10 contiguous wetland cells (approximately 5 ha each).

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|MERP Shoot decomposition litter bag study data (1986-1988) methods
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|This short-term litter bag study was conducted to examine the decomposition of emergent macrophytes (Typha glauca syn. Typha × glauca, Phragmites australis, Scolochloa festucacea, Scirpus lacustris and Scirpus maritimus syn Schoenoplectus maritimus) that dominated during the first year of reflooding (1985; Nelson, 1988; Wrubleski, Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, unpublished).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Procedures followed in the 1986-1988 Shoot Decomposition Study were the same as those described for the 1985-1987 ‘Decomposition of Mud-flat Species’ litterbag study (stored in a separate data package on the KNB). Dead above-water shoots of each of the five emergent macrophytes were collected on 23 April 1986. A subsample of each species was retained as a control for nutrient analysis. A second subsample of material was oven dried at 80 degrees Celcius and used to estimate the initial oven-dry weight of each bag (note that this data is not included in the data file; see the fresh_wt metadata for the fresh to oven dry weight conversion factor). One hundred and fifty litter bags were made for each species. Thirty litter bag sites were selected for each species, three in each of the 10 marshes. Sites were selected to span the range of elevations in which each species was observed during 1985, and the same litter bag sites were used as in the 1985-1987 study (a yellow ribbon on each site marker post separated litter bags from the 1985-1987 and 1986-1988 studies). In addition, thirty new sites will be established at locations selected to range across elevations over which each species was observed growing during 1985. For each species, sites were within stands of the same species. Five litter bags for each species were deployed at each sampling site on 26 May – 3 June 1986. Bags were retrieved 28 May – 5 June (48 hours), 14 – 18 July (49 days), 20 – 21 July 1987 (418 days) and 30 – 31 May 1988 (730 days) (note that although five litter bags were deployed per site, there were only four collection dates; therefore, on the final collection date, often two litter bags were collected. As this study was never published, no reason can be given as to why this change in methodology was made and therefore, the data should be used with caution). Water depth was recorded at the time of litter bag collection (Nelson, 1988; Wrubleski, Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, unpublished).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Lab methods followed that conducted for the 1985-1987 litter bag study. Similar to the 1985-1987 ‘Decomposition of Mud-flat Species’ litterbag study, to reduce the number of samples that were analyzed for nitrogen, phosphorus and carbon, ground litter samples were pooled by species, water depth and collection date. Water depths were stratified into 30 cm intervals, i.e. 0 cm = unflooded, 1-30 cm = shallow, 31-60 cm = medium and >60 cm = deep. The percent dry weight, nitrogen, phosphorus and carbon remaining could be calculated for each bag based on values from the initial control samples (Nelson, 1988; Wrubleski, Murkin, van der Valk and Nelson, unpublished).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Notes on reading the data:
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Entries left blank in columns between 2 commas represent that the sample was not able to be taken and/or recorded properly and is considered 'lost' information (e.g. where there is no lb_num and therefore no fresh_wt for a particular litterbag), or, where cell=0, all other columns are blank, except for nutrients, because this represents a control litter bag.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Zeros used as values represent that a particular parameter was measured (e.g. water depth) and the value was zero, or as a categorical variable (i.e. for cell_num, 0=control)
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|References:
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Nelson, J.W. 1988. Decomposition. In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Eds.) H.R. Murkin and E.J. Murkin, pp. 57-65. Manitoba, Canada: Delta Waterfowl Research Station.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Wrubleski, D.A., H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and J.W. Nelson. Decomposition of Plant Litter in a Newly Flooded Northern Prairie Marsh. Unpublished manuscript.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Marsh Ecology Research Program: Objectives, study area and experimental design (1980-1989)
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Introduction
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Good et al. (1978) and Greeson et al. (1978) were among the first to summarize the state of our understanding in freshwater wetland ecology. They emphasized the need for expanded interdisciplinary research in freshwater wetlands. Ten years later, van der Valk (1989), in Northern Prairie Wetlands, focused specifically on prairie wetlands and the influence of water-level changes on the dynamics and productivity of these systems.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Primary production, secondary production, vegetation composition and distribution, animal use, and nutrient budgets are all affected as water levels rise and fall with variation in precipitation. Ranging from tiny potholes to huge lacustrine complexes, prairie wetlands are among the world's most productive ecosystems (Murkin, 1989a). Their importance as wildlife production areas has drawn considerable attention to their conservation and management (Weller, 1978; Weller, 1981). This attention has increased in recent years with the need for information on the overall functions and values of wetlands within the prairie landscape (Murkin, 1998). Understanding wetland values is critical to the development of comprehensive wetland conservation programs. In addition, the ongoing destruction of wetlands through drainage, urban sprawl, and other human-induced changes has added a great deal of urgency to the need for a better understanding of the ecology and management of all remaining wetland areas (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Objectives
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Recognizing the need for an improved understanding of prairie wetland ecology, the Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP) was initiated in 1979 as a joint project of
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Ducks Unlimited Canada and the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station (Murkin et al., 1984). The MERP was designed as a long-term replicated experiment addressing the impacts of various water levels on the main components of the prairie wetland ecosystem. The overall objective of MERP was to document the changes that occur within a prairie wetland during a simulated wet-dry cycle (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). More specifically, MERP was designed to determine the storage (pools) and movement (fluxes) of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and carbon (C) during the various stages of the cycle (Murkin et al., 2000a). Specific objectives for each of the major ecosystem components were as follows:
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|1. Hydrology: to estimate the terms of the water budget during all stages of the wet-dry cycle: surface water in and out, ground water in and out, change in storage, precipitation, and evapotranspiration.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|2. Water chemistry: to estimate the concentrations of N, P, C, and major ions in both surface and substrate pore-water pools and to monitor changes in these pools during the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|3. Macrophytes: to estimate annual above- and below ground macrophyte productivity and standing crops and subsequent changes related to the wet-dry cycle. Storage and movement of N, P, and C in macrophytes during the wet-dry cycle also were determined.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|4. Macrophyte litter: to estimate the annual production of above- and belowground macrophyte litter and the loss and uptake of N, P, and C to and from the litter compartment.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|5. Algae: to estimate algal standing crops and productivity (phytoplankton, epiphyton, epipelon, and metaphyton) during the various stages of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|6. Invertebrates: to estimate standing crops of invertebrates (nekton, benthos, and emerging insects) during the various phases of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|7. Vertebrates: to monitor use by waterfowl, coots, blackbirds, and muskrats in response to habitat changes during the wet- dry cycle.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP experimental design and field-sampling protocols were developed to meet these objectives. Nutrient data were used to construct nutrient budgets for the experimental cells. Several additional objectives beyond those related specifically to nutrient storage and movement also were addressed. Examples are rate of recovery of plant communities following drawdown (Welling et al., 1988a), habitat use by various vertebrate groups during specific stages of the wet-dry cycle (Clark and Kroeker, 1993), and the effect of the wet-dry cycle on individual invertebrate species (Ross and Murkin, 1993; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Study Area
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP study area was located on the Delta Marsh in south-central Manitoba, Canada (5011'N, 98°19'W). The Delta Marsh is a large lacustrine marsh (15,000 ha) along the southern shore of Lake Manitoba (see Batt, 2000). The marsh is of Pleistocene origin and is a remnant of glacial Lake Agassiz (Löve and Löve, 1954, Ehrlich et al., 1957). An important feature of the marsh is that its water level has been stabilized for many years (due to installation of a water-control structure on Lake Manitoba in 1961), resulting in lake marsh conditions described by van der Valk and Davis (1978) over much of its area (Murkin et al., 2000a). The site for the MERP experimental complex was chosen because of several features. First, the area had representative portions of shallow- and deep-marsh zones characteristic of the Delta Marsh and other northern prairie marshes. Second, the area was remote and completely within the private ownership of the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station, thus ensuring access for researchers, while affording effective control of trespass and disturbance. Third, the site was served by an existing road system. This road system was crucial, given the large number of individuals working on the site each day; the large numbers and volumes of water, soil, vegetation, and animal samples to be handled; and the logistics of transporting and maintaining sampling devices. Finally, the existing road provided the northern boundary of the experimental cells, thereby reducing construction costs. The water levels used in the experiments were chosen to reflect conditions that had occurred naturally during the previous 5 decades. Thus, the experimental site and design has provided information that is relevant to any future management efforts on the Delta Marsh, specifically, and wetland management in general.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The experimental cell complex consisted of 10 contiguous 4-6 ha marsh units (Cells 1-10), created in 1979 by building a series of dikes along the northern edge of the main marsh. The diked experimental cells were numbered 1 to 10 from west to east. The approximate dimension of each diked cell was 150m x 300m (see Table 1 for the specific dimensions of each cell). Disturbance due to dike construction was confined to the dikes and a 10m buffer strip on each side of the dike. Each diked cell was equipped with a water control structure and electric pump with automatic controls to adjust and maintain (2cm) water levels according to the schedule (see Table 2). Besides the diked cells, two undiked areas of similar size within the Delta Marsh (Cells 11 & 12) were monitored as reference cells (i.e. reference cells to the unmanipulated Delta Marsh). The vegetation within the diked cells prior to the experimental treatments was comparable to the reference cells and main Delta Marsh (Pederson 1981; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Experimental Design
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The general MERP objective was to monitor the response of various aspects of the wetland ecosystem to a series of water-level manipulations intended to simulate the wet-dry cycle of prairie wetlands. The schedule for water-level treatments and the number of replicates for each treatment are shown in Tables 2 and 3. The study was basically divided into four phases. The first two phases (baseline and deep flooding) were designed to provide background information on the experimental cells and to bring all cells to a similar condition (lake marsh stage) before the actual wet-dry cycle was applied during the last two phases (drawdown and reflooding; Murkin et al., 2000a). The four phases of the experimental design were as follows:
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|a. Baseline year (1980-1981):
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|During the first year of the study (1980), the control structures were left open and water levels within the cells were allowed to track the levels of the Delta Marsh. This method provided a year of baseline data before the actual water-level manipulations began. Two of the cells (3 and 7) were kept at baseline levels for a second year (1981) to allow for comparison of different durations of drawdown later in the study (see Table 3).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|b. Deep flooding (aka Conditioning Period; 1981-1983):
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Following the baseline year(s), all diked cells were flooded to ~ 1 m above normal for a period of 2 years (Table 2). These levels were designed to flood the existing cattail (Typha spp.) stands to a depth of 1 m and were similar to actual natural high-water levels that occurred in the Delta Marsh in the 1950s. This deep flooding was intended to kill the existing emergent vegetation and set all the cells to the lake marsh stage described by van der Valk and Davis (1978). In part, deep flooding was also an attempt to reduce the variability in vegetation among the experimental cells prior to drawdown.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|c. Drawdown (1983-1984):
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|After the second year of above-normal flooding, the cells were drawn down (completely dewatered) by adjusting the water levels to 50 cm below the long-term level of the Delta Marsh (Table 2). Most cells were exposed to a 2-year drawdown. Two cells (3 and 7) were drawn down for 1 year to allow comparisons between drawdowns of 1- and 2-year durations. The drawdowns allowed vegetation to reestablish on the marsh substrates (Welling et al., 1988a, b).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|d. Reflooding (1985-1989):
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|It has been assumed that the rate at which prairie wetlands proceed through the various stages of the wet-dry cycle is determined by water depth, with deeper wetlands moving to the lake marsh stage more quickly than shallowly flooded wetlands (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). Following drawdown, the cells were reflooded to three different levels (Table 3). The normal level was the long-term mean level (247.50 m above mean sea level [AMSL]) of the Delta Marsh and the medium (247.80 m) and high (248.10 m) levels were 30 and 60 cm above the long-term mean, respectively (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To ensure replicated treatments (on a hydrologic basis) during the reflooding experiments in 1985-1989, water-level treatments were assigned to the experimental cells as follows: the two low-water treatments with a 1-year drawdown (Table 3) were randomly assigned to the experimental complex, and the remaining treatments were then assigned to the other cells to ensure that each cell within a water-level treatment had a similar hydrologic setting (i.e. both low cells with 1-year drawdowns were flanked by cells with low and high treatments, both low 2-year drawdown cells by low and medium treatments, all medium treatment cells by high- and low-treatment cells, and the high-treatment cells by medium and low cells). This replicated hydrology is discussed in more detail in Kadlec (1983, 1993). The treatment assignments for the 1985-1989 period (Table 3) determined the water-level assignments during the early phases of the MERP experiments from 1981 to 1984 (Table 2).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Long-term Monitoring Program
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The Scientific Team designed a program of standardized methods to monitor the experimental cells throughout the period of study. The basic strategy was to collect a comparable data set from year to year in each experimental cell for each of the major components being monitored, including hydrology, water chemistry, macrophytes, macrophyte litter, algae, invertebrates and vertebrates (Murkin et al., 2000a; Murkin, 1989b). The MERP long-term monitoring program involved a variety of techniques that were used to provide comparable datasets across the experimental cells and over the 10 years of fieldwork. Some of the techniques used were new, but most were adopted from other researchers. All have been modified to suit the needs for efficiency, economy and practicality for long-term large-scale ecosystem research (Murkin et al., 2000b). Each component has a section in the MERP Data Archive describing the techniques used.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Short-term Studies
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Besides the long-term monitoring program, short-term studies were an integral component of the overall MERP program. Some of these studies provided background information needed to develop the long-term monitoring program (Pederson, 1981; Wrubleski, 1984). Some were integrated into the long-term monitoring program (Murkin, 1983a; Galinato, 1985; Hosseini, 1986; Welling, 1987; Merendino, 1989). Several aspects of the long-term monitoring program following drawdown began as short-term studies (Kroeker, 1988; Squires, 1991; Wrubleksi, 1991). Many of the short-term studies, however, were initiated because of questions raised by the long-term monitoring program. This approach was particularly true for studies of invertebrates (Nelson, 1982; Neckles, 1984; Bicknese, 1987; Campeau, 1990) and emergent macrophytes (Neill, 1988; Neill, 1992). Many of the short-term studies were conducted by graduate studies, a list of which can be found in merp_pubs_appx3_prairie_wetland_ecology_pdfa.pdf and whose theses can be found in the merp_publications_theses file (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Main Transects, Work Lanes and Sampling Procedure
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To aid in the assignment of sampling stations, each cell was divided into 10 zones. Zone boundaries were parallel to the southern dike. To determine the zones, 10 areas of equal width were established between a line 10 m north of the south dike and a second line 10 m south of the road on the northern edge of the cell. These zones were permanently marked so they could be located from year to year.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Each year, ten transects were randomly established within each cell, 1 per zone, numbered from north to south. These transects or ‘work lanes’ were used for all types of routine sampling, in order to minimize disturbance and confine it within a designated region. All sampling took place as near as possible to the work lane. When a sampling point was some distance from the work lane, a path perpendicular to the work lane was established. Work lanes were reassigned each fall following the last day of sampling (Murkin, 1989b; Murkin et al., 2000b).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|A standard sampling procedure was maintained during all transect sampling. One or two random transects in each cell were sampled, repeating the same method for each cell until all samples were secured, rather than sampling all transects in a cell before moving on to the next cell. This randomized any effect due to time during the sampling period. As standard procedure, water depth at the sampling site was recorded during all types of sampling (Murkin, 1983b).
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Additional data packages generated from the Marsh Ecology Research Program can also be found on the Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity (KNB):
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|AERIAL MAPS & GIS
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Aerial photos, cover maps and GIS data (1980-1989)
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|ALGAE:
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Algal data transect sampling (1985-1989)

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|12 150 320 32 5.75
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|a - measured from a point 10m east of the borrow ditch to a second point 10m west of the east dike. Since the width of an individual cell varies from north to south these are the mean values.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|b - measured from a line 10m north of the south dike to a parallel line 10m south of the north edge of the cell.

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/@id|1322065192546
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/entityName|MERP Shoot decomposition litter bag study data (1986-1988)
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/entityDescription|This data package contains data from the shoot decomposition litter bag study (1986-1988). Litter bag studies were a series of short-term studies, conducted as part of the decomposition study of MERP (1980-1989). Additional litter bag studies can be found in separate data packages on the KNB.
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/physical/@id|1322064449109
KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/physical/objectName|merp_decomp_lb1986-1988_data.csv

KNB|00707-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|initial sample weight, air dried at 20 degrees C (approximately 10 - 15 g). note:in order to compare with final_odw (i.e. oven dry weight versus fresh weight), a subsample of material was oven dried at 80 degrees celcius and used to estimate the initial oven-dry weight of each bag by applying a fresh to oven weight conversion factor: if species = 010103 then corrected weight (orig_odw) = fresh_wt*0.943 if species = 020101 then corrected weight (orig_odw) = fresh_wt*0.926 if species = 020201 then corrected weight (orig_odw) = fresh_wt*0.931 if species = 030100 then corrected weight (orig_odw) = fresh_wt*0.914 if species = 030103 then corrected weight (orig_odw) = fresh_wt*0.934

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/deliveryPoint|P.O. Box 1160
