KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/country|Canada
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|The Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP) was a long-term interdisciplinary study on the ecology of prairie wetlands. A scientific team from a variety of disciplines (hydrology, plant ecology, invertebrate ecology, vertebrate ecology, nutrient dynamics, marsh management) was assembled to design and oversee a long-term experiment on the effects of water-level manipulation on northern prairie wetlands. Ten years of fieldwork (1980 -1989), combining a routine long-term monitoring program and a series of short-term studies, generated a wealth of new and diverse information on the ecology and function of prairie wetlands (Murkin, Batt, Caldwell, Kadlec and van der Valk, 2000). This data set includes soil nutrient and site vegetation characetization data for all groundwater well sites. The main objective for monitoring soil nutrients in the MERP was to quantify sediments as a nutrient pool in wetlands and to characterize the sediments of the MERP cells over time. Along with monitoring the other major nutrient pools (surface water, plants and plant litter, animals and interstitial waters), yearly changes in the sediment nutrient pool can provide important information on the nutrient cycling within wetlands. In addition, the effects of deep flooding and drawdown on nutrients in marsh sediments was also evaluated (Kadlec, 1985a; Kadlec, 1985b; Kaldec, 1989). For further information on the Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP), please visit: http://www.ducks.ca/conserve/research/projects/merp/index.html References: Kadlec, J.A. 1985a. Nutrient dynamics. In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Ed.) H.R. Murkin, pp. 27-40. Manitoba , Canada: Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station. Kadlec, J.A. 1985b. Physical environment In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Ed.) H.R. Murkin, pp. 15-17. Manitoba , Canada: Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station. Kadlec, J.A. 1989. Effects of deep flooding and drawdown on freshwater marsh sediments. In: Freshwater Wetlands and Wildlife. (Eds.) R.R. Sharitz and J.W. Gibbons, pp. 127-143. USDOE Symposium Series 61, USDOE Office of Scientific and Technical Information, Oak Ridge. Murkin, H.R., B.D.J. Batt, P.J. Caldwell, J.A. Kadlec and A.G. van der Valk. 2000a. Introduction to the Marsh Ecology Research Program. In Prairie Wetland Ecology: The Contribution of the Marsh Ecology Research Program. (Eds) H.R. Murkin, A.G. van der Valk and W.R. Clark. pp. 3-15. Ames: Iowa State University Press. Resulting Publications on MERP soil nutrients data: Kadlec, J.A. 1989. Effects of deep flooding and drawdown on freshwater marsh sediments. In: Freshwater Wetlands and Wildlife. (Eds.) R.R. Sharitz and J.W. Gibbons, pp. 127-143. USDOE Symposium Series 61, USDOE Office of Scientific and Technical Information, Oak Ridge.

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/coverage/geographicCoverage/geographicDescription|Marsh Ecology Research Complex: The MERP study area was located on the Delta Marsh in south central Manitoba, Canada. The Delta Marsh is a large lacustrine marsh (approximately 50,000 ha) along the southern shore of Lake Manitoba. The experimental complex consisted of 10 contiguous wetland cells (approximately 5 ha each).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/coverage/geographicCoverage/boundingCoordinates/westBoundingCoordinate|-98.22

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|MERP Soil nutrients and groundwater well site characterization data (1980-1985) methods
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Soil samples were collected on an annual basis for nutrient analysis, during the last week of June or early July (with the exception of 1984, when samples were collected in August and October). Soil samples were collected at five groundwater well sites per cell (in all cells except 9, where samples were collected from the 10 groundwater (GW) well sites), using the invertebrate core sampler (5 cm inner diameter, 20 cm length; Kadlec, 1985a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Enough cores were taken to completely fill a wide-mouth Mason jar, which was labeled with the date, and groundwater well number. All soil nutrient samples were sent to the Provincial Soil Testing Lab at the University of Manitoba in Winnipeg (Manitoba, Canada), to determine total nitrogen, available nitrogen, total phosphorous, available phosphorous, total sulpher, available potassium, sediment water content (as a percent of the soil dry weight) and percent organic matter (added in 1983). A master sheet with sample numbers 1-65 was used to keep track of each sample. As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred the sample boxes provided by the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). All anaylses were performed on wet samples. The analytic procedure was modified so that subsamples for analyses of available N (NO3--N + NO2-N), available P (dissolved and some adsorbed P), and available K were not dried prior to extraction, as drying affects extractable quantities of most ions in organic soils (Kadlec, 1989; Anderson and Beverly, 1985; Gilliam and Richter, 1985). N and P subsamples were extracted with 0.5M NaHCO3 at pH 8.5 and K subsamples with 1N NH4OAc at pH 7. The N and P extracts were analyzed on a Technicon Auto Analyzer, N by a modification of the procedure of Kampshake et al. (1967) and P by the ascorbic acid-ammonium molybdate method (Page et al., 1982). K was analyzed by flame photometry. Analyses for total P and total S were performed on dried sediment samples which were digested with HNO3 and HClO4. Total N was determined by the Kjeldahl method. Organic matter was determined by the potassium dichromate reduction procedure (Page et al., 1982).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|In addition to the Manitoba Provincial Soil Testing Laboratory measured sediment water content, at the field laboratory, separate known volume cores, taken at the same time as the cores for nutrient analysis, were analyzed for dry weight and water per unit volume. However, this data was not able to be archived. Because of the range in sediment consistency in the marshes, Kaldec (1989) was also not confident that the coring technique provided accurate data for bulk density calculations. Nevertheless, it was the best available procedure for largescale routine use at the time.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Sampling for the characterization of macrophytes at groundwater well sites occurred once in late July or early August during the sampling season, as this is the period where standing emergents reach their maximum standing crop. The groundwater well sites were examined for plant species present, density or percent cover, and live or dead plants. To characterize the sites, a square meter quadrat was randomly placed within a 2 metre radius of the well site. Within the quadrat, the number of stems of emergent or upland species were counted. For submergent species, a percent cover value in the total quadrat area was estimated. Macrophytes were coded to species when possible. For the 1982 sampling year only, surveys also recorded if the species was live or dead.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Notes on reading the data:
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-Note that, for 1982 soil nutrient analyses, TN, TP and TS at all marsh sites (including the control cells 11 &12) decreased significantly, as compared to soil nutrient values for all other years. No explanation related to the experiment could be provided from the Kadlec (1989) publication, as well as from consultation with soil nutrient experts, for this anomalous data. As QA/QC data were not available for the Manitoba Provincial Soil Testing Laboratory reports for 1982, the possibility of an error related to laboratory analyses should not be overlooked. Therefore, the 1982 soil nutrient data should be treated with caution.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-For nutrient analyses on soil samples, zero values indicate that a particular parameter was measured and its’ value was zero.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-For nutrient analyses on soil samples, blanks for a particular parameter indicate that an insufficient amount of sample was available to run a particular analysis, that a sample was not able to be taken/recorded properly and that information is considered to be lost, or that a particular parameter was not recorded in that sampling year (i.e. percent organic matter for 1980-1982).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-For 1982 soil nutrient analyses, TN, TP and TS at all marsh sites (including the control cells 11 &12) decreased significantly, as compared to soil nutrient values for all other years. No explanation could be provided in the Kadlec (1989) publication, as well as from consultation with soil nutrient experts, for this anomalous data. As QA/QC data were not available for the Manitoba Provincial Soil Testing Laboratory reports for 1982, the possibility of an error related to laboratory analyses should not be overlooked. Therefore, the 1982 soil nutrient data should be treated with caution.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-For vegetation data on groundwater well site characterizations, zero values for both quadrat density/percent cover value and species indicates that there was no vegetation at that particular groundwater well site.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-For vegetation data on groundwater well site characterizations, a blank entry indicates:
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-where a particular parameter was not recorded for that sampling year (i.e. ‘live or dead’ in all sampling years but 1982), or
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-that a sample was not able to be taken/recorded properly at that groundwater well site and that the information is considered to be lost, or
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|-a total for all other (unknown or minor) ‘live’ or ‘dead’ species, where the ‘plant species present’ parameter is blank, but a value for ‘live or dead’ and ‘density or cover value’ is given (1982 only).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|References
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Anderson, D.L. and R.B. Beverly. 1985. The effects of drying upon extractable P, K and bulk density of organic and mineral soils of the Everglades. Soil Science Society of America 49: 362-366.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Gilliam, F.S. and D.D. Richter. 1985. Increases in extractable ions in infertile aquults caused by sample preparation. Soil Society of America Journal 49: 1576-1578.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Kadlec, J.A. 1985a. Nutrient dynamics. In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Ed.) H.R. Murkin, pp. 27-40. Manitoba , Canada: Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Kadlec, J.A. 1985b. Physical environment In: Marsh Ecology Research Program: Long-term Monitoring Procedures Manual. (Ed.) H.R. Murkin, pp. 15-17. Manitoba , Canada: Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Kadlec, J.A. 1989. Effects of deep flooding and drawdown on freshwater marsh sediments. In: Freshwater Wetlands and Wildlife. (Eds.) R.R. Sharitz and J.W. Gibbons, pp. 127-143. USDOE Symposium Series 61, USDOE Office of Scientific and Technical Information, Oak Ridge.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Kampshake, L.J., S.A. Hannah and J.M. Cohen. 1967. Automated analysis for nitrate by hydrazine reduction. Water Resources Research 1: 205-216.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Marsh Ecology Research Program: Objectives, study area and experimental design (1980-1989)
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Introduction
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Good et al. (1978) and Greeson et al. (1978) were among the first to summarize the state of our understanding in freshwater wetland ecology. They emphasized the need for expanded interdisciplinary research in freshwater wetlands. Ten years later, van der Valk (1989), in Northern Prairie Wetlands, focused specifically on prairie wetlands and the influence of water-level changes on the dynamics and productivity of these systems.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Primary production, secondary production, vegetation composition and distribution, animal use, and nutrient budgets are all affected as water levels rise and fall with variation in precipitation. Ranging from tiny potholes to huge lacustrine complexes, prairie wetlands are among the world's most productive ecosystems (Murkin, 1989a). Their importance as wildlife production areas has drawn considerable attention to their conservation and management (Weller, 1978; Weller, 1981). This attention has increased in recent years with the need for information on the overall functions and values of wetlands within the prairie landscape (Murkin, 1998). Understanding wetland values is critical to the development of comprehensive wetland conservation programs. In addition, the ongoing destruction of wetlands through drainage, urban sprawl, and other human-induced changes has added a great deal of urgency to the need for a better understanding of the ecology and management of all remaining wetland areas (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Objectives
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Recognizing the need for an improved understanding of prairie wetland ecology, the Marsh Ecology Research Program (MERP) was initiated in 1979 as a joint project of
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Ducks Unlimited Canada and the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station (Murkin et al., 1984). The MERP was designed as a long-term replicated experiment addressing the impacts of various water levels on the main components of the prairie wetland ecosystem. The overall objective of MERP was to document the changes that occur within a prairie wetland during a simulated wet-dry cycle (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). More specifically, MERP was designed to determine the storage (pools) and movement (fluxes) of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and carbon (C) during the various stages of the cycle (Murkin et al., 2000a). Specific objectives for each of the major ecosystem components were as follows:
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|1. Hydrology: to estimate the terms of the water budget during all stages of the wet-dry cycle: surface water in and out, ground water in and out, change in storage, precipitation, and evapotranspiration.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|2. Water chemistry: to estimate the concentrations of N, P, C, and major ions in both surface and substrate pore-water pools and to monitor changes in these pools during the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|3. Macrophytes: to estimate annual above- and below ground macrophyte productivity and standing crops and subsequent changes related to the wet-dry cycle. Storage and movement of N, P, and C in macrophytes during the wet-dry cycle also were determined.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|4. Macrophyte litter: to estimate the annual production of above- and belowground macrophyte litter and the loss and uptake of N, P, and C to and from the litter compartment.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|5. Algae: to estimate algal standing crops and productivity (phytoplankton, epiphyton, epipelon, and metaphyton) during the various stages of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|6. Invertebrates: to estimate standing crops of invertebrates (nekton, benthos, and emerging insects) during the various phases of the wet-dry cycle.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|7. Vertebrates: to monitor use by waterfowl, coots, blackbirds, and muskrats in response to habitat changes during the wet- dry cycle.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP experimental design and field-sampling protocols were developed to meet these objectives. Nutrient data were used to construct nutrient budgets for the experimental cells. Several additional objectives beyond those related specifically to nutrient storage and movement also were addressed. Examples are rate of recovery of plant communities following drawdown (Welling et al., 1988a), habitat use by various vertebrate groups during specific stages of the wet-dry cycle (Clark and Kroeker, 1993), and the effect of the wet-dry cycle on individual invertebrate species (Ross and Murkin, 1993; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Study Area
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The MERP study area was located on the Delta Marsh in south-central Manitoba, Canada (5011'N, 98°19'W). The Delta Marsh is a large lacustrine marsh (15,000 ha) along the southern shore of Lake Manitoba (see Batt, 2000). The marsh is of Pleistocene origin and is a remnant of glacial Lake Agassiz (Löve and Löve, 1954, Ehrlich et al., 1957). An important feature of the marsh is that its water level has been stabilized for many years (due to installation of a water-control structure on Lake Manitoba in 1961), resulting in lake marsh conditions described by van der Valk and Davis (1978) over much of its area (Murkin et al., 2000a). The site for the MERP experimental complex was chosen because of several features. First, the area had representative portions of shallow- and deep-marsh zones characteristic of the Delta Marsh and other northern prairie marshes. Second, the area was remote and completely within the private ownership of the Delta Waterfowl and Wetlands Research Station, thus ensuring access for researchers, while affording effective control of trespass and disturbance. Third, the site was served by an existing road system. This road system was crucial, given the large number of individuals working on the site each day; the large numbers and volumes of water, soil, vegetation, and animal samples to be handled; and the logistics of transporting and maintaining sampling devices. Finally, the existing road provided the northern boundary of the experimental cells, thereby reducing construction costs. The water levels used in the experiments were chosen to reflect conditions that had occurred naturally during the previous 5 decades. Thus, the experimental site and design has provided information that is relevant to any future management efforts on the Delta Marsh, specifically, and wetland management in general.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The experimental cell complex consisted of 10 contiguous 4-6 ha marsh units (Cells 1-10), created in 1979 by building a series of dikes along the northern edge of the main marsh. The diked experimental cells were numbered 1 to 10 from west to east. The approximate dimension of each diked cell was 150m x 300m (see Table 1 for the specific dimensions of each cell). Disturbance due to dike construction was confined to the dikes and a 10m buffer strip on each side of the dike. Each diked cell was equipped with a water control structure and electric pump with automatic controls to adjust and maintain (2cm) water levels according to the schedule (see Table 2). Besides the diked cells, two undiked areas of similar size within the Delta Marsh (Cells 11 & 12) were monitored as reference cells (i.e. reference cells to the unmanipulated Delta Marsh). The vegetation within the diked cells prior to the experimental treatments was comparable to the reference cells and main Delta Marsh (Pederson 1981; Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Experimental Design
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The general MERP objective was to monitor the response of various aspects of the wetland ecosystem to a series of water-level manipulations intended to simulate the wet-dry cycle of prairie wetlands. The schedule for water-level treatments and the number of replicates for each treatment are shown in Tables 2 and 3. The study was basically divided into four phases. The first two phases (baseline and deep flooding) were designed to provide background information on the experimental cells and to bring all cells to a similar condition (lake marsh stage) before the actual wet-dry cycle was applied during the last two phases (drawdown and reflooding; Murkin et al., 2000a). The four phases of the experimental design were as follows:
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|a. Baseline year (1980-1981):
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|During the first year of the study (1980), the control structures were left open and water levels within the cells were allowed to track the levels of the Delta Marsh. This method provided a year of baseline data before the actual water-level manipulations began. Two of the cells (3 and 7) were kept at baseline levels for a second year (1981) to allow for comparison of different durations of drawdown later in the study (see Table 3).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|b. Deep flooding (aka Conditioning Period; 1981-1983):
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Following the baseline year(s), all diked cells were flooded to ~ 1 m above normal for a period of 2 years (Table 2). These levels were designed to flood the existing cattail (Typha spp.) stands to a depth of 1 m and were similar to actual natural high-water levels that occurred in the Delta Marsh in the 1950s. This deep flooding was intended to kill the existing emergent vegetation and set all the cells to the lake marsh stage described by van der Valk and Davis (1978). In part, deep flooding was also an attempt to reduce the variability in vegetation among the experimental cells prior to drawdown.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|c. Drawdown (1983-1984):
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|After the second year of above-normal flooding, the cells were drawn down (completely dewatered) by adjusting the water levels to 50 cm below the long-term level of the Delta Marsh (Table 2). Most cells were exposed to a 2-year drawdown. Two cells (3 and 7) were drawn down for 1 year to allow comparisons between drawdowns of 1- and 2-year durations. The drawdowns allowed vegetation to reestablish on the marsh substrates (Welling et al., 1988a, b).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|d. Reflooding (1985-1989):
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|It has been assumed that the rate at which prairie wetlands proceed through the various stages of the wet-dry cycle is determined by water depth, with deeper wetlands moving to the lake marsh stage more quickly than shallowly flooded wetlands (van der Valk and Davis, 1978). Following drawdown, the cells were reflooded to three different levels (Table 3). The normal level was the long-term mean level (247.50 m above mean sea level [AMSL]) of the Delta Marsh and the medium (247.80 m) and high (248.10 m) levels were 30 and 60 cm above the long-term mean, respectively (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To ensure replicated treatments (on a hydrologic basis) during the reflooding experiments in 1985-1989, water-level treatments were assigned to the experimental cells as follows: the two low-water treatments with a 1-year drawdown (Table 3) were randomly assigned to the experimental complex, and the remaining treatments were then assigned to the other cells to ensure that each cell within a water-level treatment had a similar hydrologic setting (i.e. both low cells with 1-year drawdowns were flanked by cells with low and high treatments, both low 2-year drawdown cells by low and medium treatments, all medium treatment cells by high- and low-treatment cells, and the high-treatment cells by medium and low cells). This replicated hydrology is discussed in more detail in Kadlec (1983, 1993). The treatment assignments for the 1985-1989 period (Table 3) determined the water-level assignments during the early phases of the MERP experiments from 1981 to 1984 (Table 2).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Long-term Monitoring Program
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The Scientific Team designed a program of standardized methods to monitor the experimental cells throughout the period of study. The basic strategy was to collect a comparable data set from year to year in each experimental cell for each of the major components being monitored, including hydrology, water chemistry, macrophytes, macrophyte litter, algae, invertebrates and vertebrates (Murkin et al., 2000a; Murkin, 1989b). The MERP long-term monitoring program involved a variety of techniques that were used to provide comparable datasets across the experimental cells and over the 10 years of fieldwork. Some of the techniques used were new, but most were adopted from other researchers. All have been modified to suit the needs for efficiency, economy and practicality for long-term large-scale ecosystem research (Murkin et al., 2000b). Each component has a section in the MERP Data Archive describing the techniques used.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Short-term Studies
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Besides the long-term monitoring program, short-term studies were an integral component of the overall MERP program. Some of these studies provided background information needed to develop the long-term monitoring program (Pederson, 1981; Wrubleski, 1984). Some were integrated into the long-term monitoring program (Murkin, 1983a; Galinato, 1985; Hosseini, 1986; Welling, 1987; Merendino, 1989). Several aspects of the long-term monitoring program following drawdown began as short-term studies (Kroeker, 1988; Squires, 1991; Wrubleksi, 1991). Many of the short-term studies, however, were initiated because of questions raised by the long-term monitoring program. This approach was particularly true for studies of invertebrates (Nelson, 1982; Neckles, 1984; Bicknese, 1987; Campeau, 1990) and emergent macrophytes (Neill, 1988; Neill, 1992). Many of the short-term studies were conducted by graduate studies, a list of which can be found in merp_pubs_appx3_prairie_wetland_ecology_pdfa.pdf and whose theses can be found in the merp_publications_theses file (Murkin et al., 2000a).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Main Transects, Work Lanes and Sampling Procedure
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|To aid in the assignment of sampling stations, each cell was divided into 10 zones. Zone boundaries were parallel to the southern dike. To determine the zones, 10 areas of equal width were established between a line 10 m north of the south dike and a second line 10 m south of the road on the northern edge of the cell. These zones were permanently marked so they could be located from year to year.
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Each year, ten transects were randomly established within each cell, 1 per zone, numbered from north to south. These transects or ‘work lanes’ were used for all types of routine sampling, in order to minimize disturbance and confine it within a designated region. All sampling took place as near as possible to the work lane. When a sampling point was some distance from the work lane, a path perpendicular to the work lane was established. Work lanes were reassigned each fall following the last day of sampling (Murkin, 1989b; Murkin et al., 2000b).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|A standard sampling procedure was maintained during all transect sampling. One or two random transects in each cell were sampled, repeating the same method for each cell until all samples were secured, rather than sampling all transects in a cell before moving on to the next cell. This randomized any effect due to time during the sampling period. As standard procedure, water depth at the sampling site was recorded during all types of sampling (Murkin, 1983b).
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Additional data packages generated from the Marsh Ecology Research Program can also be found on the Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity (KNB):

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|References

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1321298803453
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|avail_N
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|available Nitrogen (ppm)
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred to the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). All anaylses were performed on wet samples. The analytic procedure was modified so that subsamples for analyses of available N (NO3--N + NO2-N) were not dried prior to extraction, as drying affects extractable quantities of most ions in organic soils (Kadlec, 1989; Anderson and Beverly, 1985; Gilliam and Richter, 1985). N subsamples were extracted with 0.5M NaHCO3 at pH 8.5 The N extracts were analyzed on a Technicon Auto Analyzer, N by a modification of the procedure of Kampshake et al. (1967).

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred to the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). Total N was determined by the Kjeldahl method.

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1321298803484
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|avail_P
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|available Phosphorus (ppm)
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred to the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). All anaylses were performed on wet samples. The analytic procedure was modified so that subsamples for analyses of available P (dissolved and some adsorbed P) were not dried prior to extraction, as drying affects extractable quantities of most ions in organic soils (Kadlec, 1989; Anderson and Beverly, 1985; Gilliam and Richter, 1985). P subsamples were extracted with 0.5M NaHCO3 at pH 8.5. The P extracts were analyzed on a Technicon Auto Analyzer, P by the ascorbic acid-ammonium molybdate method (Page et al., 1982)

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|TP
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|Total Phosphorus (%)
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred to the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). Analyses for total P were performed on dried sediment samples which were digested with HNO3 and HClO4.

KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/@id|1321298803515
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeName|avail_K
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeLabel|Available Potassium (ppm)
KNB|00717-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/dataTable/attributeList/attribute/attributeDefinition|As per requirements of the Soil Testing Lab, each wet sediment sample was homogenized in a blender before being transferred to the Soil Testing Lab, and stored in a freezer (Kadlec, 1985a). All anaylses were performed on wet samples. The analytic procedure was modified so that subsamples for analyses of available K were not dried prior to extraction, as drying affects extractable quantities of most ions in organic soils (Kadlec, 1989; Anderson and Beverly, 1985; Gilliam and Richter, 1985). K subsamples were extracted with 1N NH4OAc at pH 7.K was analyzed by flame photometry.

KNB|00718-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2008-04-01
KNB|00718-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|Since 1959, this survey has developed indices for the abundance of young striped bass when the average size is 38 mm by sampling 31 stations from San Pablo Bay through the Delta. The original purpose was to predict recruitment to the adult stock but the index has proven valuable in gauging the environmental health of the estuary. Young striped bass abundance is primarily a function of Delta outflow, Delta water exports and egg production. Abundance indices for other species have also revealed important trends. For example, the index for delta smelt was useful in determining its status as a threatened species. This survey is mandated by the 1995 USFWS Biological Opinion (BO) for delta smelt on the operation of the SWP and CVP.

KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/@scope|document
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|Species diversity of vascular plants and day-active Lepidoptera on buffer zones in Southern Finland, 2009
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/@id|1317723201872
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/@scope|document
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/organizationName|Finnish Environmental Institute
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/@scope|document
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/deliveryPoint|P.O.Box 140, Mechelininkatu 34a
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/city|Helsinki
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/postalCode|FI-00251
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/address/country|Finland
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|The data originates from national monitoring on the effects of the Finnish agri-environment support scheme (MYTVAS). The effects of buffer zones on biodiversity were studied in a case study of 21 buffer zones of differing age in southern Finland in summer 2009. Vascular plants and day-active Lepidoptera (butterflies and moths) were studied as biodiversity indicators. Their species richness in buffer zones was compared to other linear uncultivated semi-natural habitats available in the study landscapes, i.e. forest edges and field margins, and particularly the field margin between the studied buffer zone and the neighboring waterway. In each of 21 landscapes, data was collected on ten 50 m long transect lines, of which two were located in each habitat type. Several environmental variables were evaluated on the transect lines and in surrounding landscape. The methods are described in the following publication: Heliölä, J., Virtanen, L., Sandholm, L. & Kuussaari, M. 2010b. Suojavyöhykkeiden merkitys putkilokasvien ja suurper-hosten monimuotoisuudelle. (Significance of buffer zones for the diversity of vascular plants and diurnal Macrolepi-doptera, in Finnish). In: Aakkula, J., Manninen, T. & Nurro, M. (eds.). Follow-up study on the impacts of agri-environment measures (MYTVAS 3). Mid-term report. Maa- ja metsätalousministeriön julkaisuja 1: 94-104.

KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Data on vascular plants
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Data on vascular plants was collected in June-July on the transect lines being located on the buffer zones and the field margins between the buffer zones and the neighboring waterways. The other semi-natural habitats were not included to the plant study. Coverages of vascular plant species were evaluated on the whole area of the 50 m long and 1 m wide lines by using a nine-class scale (1<0,125 %; 2=0,125 – 0,5 %; 3=0,5 - 2 %; 4=2 – 4 %; 5=4 – 8 %; 6=8 –16 %; 7=16 – 32 %; 8=32 – 64 %; 9>64 %). Additionally, coverages of plant species were evaluated per cent on two 1 x 1 m quadrates on each line. The quadrates were located so that the centre of a quadrate was at the distance of 17 m from the end of the line and 16 m from the centre of the other quadrate. In total, 84 transect lines and 168 quadrates were studied.
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Data on day-active Lepidoptera
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Monitoring of pollinators was carried out using the standard line-transect method (Pollard & Yates 1993), in which a transect route is walked at a steady speed and all individuals within a 5 x 5 m square ahead are recorded. The counts were carried out on all the 210 transect lines seven times in May-August at approximately 2-week intervals in weather conditions allowing insect activity.
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|Pollard, E. & Yates, T. 1993. Monitoring butterflies for ecology and conservation. Chapman & Hall. London, UK. 274 p.
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/title|Environmental variables
KNB|00753-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para|The environmental variables were divided into two groups: the variables measuring the local habitat quality on the transect line, and the variables measuring the quality of the surrounding landscape. Some of the variables were evaluated only on the transect lines where the plant data was collected, i.e. on the buffer zones and the field margins between the buffer zones and the neighboring waterways. The surrounding landscape was studied by mapping the coverages of different habitat types: fields, forests, meadow patches and other habitats within a radius of both 100 m and 500 m of the transect line of the studied buffer zone.

KNB|00758-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/para|Data package contains information on small-mammal trappings carried out by late Johan Tast. Research were carried out in three different biotopes (two boggy areas, one mountain heath) from 1959-2002. Measurements are: date, species, location and density index.
